body.p:
! Hebrew Although I am
fully confident that the friendship and regard which, notwithstanding
our difference of religious views, you have at various times manifested
towards me, would be satisfied with the above open and sincere
confession on my part, in reply to your message conveyed to me, last
night, by Mr. Hart, yet, to show you that I reciprocate those
feelings, I deem it incumbent upon me to give you a full explanati-
on of my long silence and seeming neglect.

It is certainly unnecessary to assure you that neither ill feeling
nor wilful disregard caused that silence; my friendship and respect
for you have not in the least diminished; I could refer to many
of your acquaintances in this place, that I do not allow any
opportunity to pass, without expressing my highest appreciation
for you; nay! I would even defend you against all insinuations
of your friends, who deem it proper to sound the praise of their
favorites at your expense; and Rev. Mr. H. P. Jacobs can tell you
that, when you announced the discontinuance of the translation of
the Cozri by Dr Fiskel (why this course?) I contemplated to
substitute the deficiency by my own translation. Circumstances
which led to my silence have prevented me to carry out that con-
templated work. So much upon this point.

And now, in the full expectation that you will make no farther
use of what I shall have to say, I will fully explain those cir-
cumstances. For the last two years, I have made the sad experience

that the path of a minister, especially of a Jewish one, is not strewn
with roses. I will not enter into details, but merely beg of you not
to base any conclusion or judgement upon what you might have
heard, or should still hear, as long as you have not heard also
the other party, my humble self Hebrew Thank God! not-
withstanding all the harassing annoyances and persecutions which
I have had to endure both on the part of those that are “with me,”
and those that are “against me,” my character stands forth
unstained and unscathed, and I have the consolation that
my course was one of the most uncompromising honesty and
straightforwardness. Yet, I must confess that all these experiences
have in so far discouraged me, that I do my duty to its fullest
extent, but abstain from all further cooperation and interference
in the religious affairs of our people, unless something national
appeals to my Jewish heart, in such cases I rush to the
post of duty with all zeal and enthusiasm. Have you read, for the last 18 months,
one line of controversy published by me in any of our Papers,
here or in Europe? I can assure you that I have received many
letters even blaming me for my inactivity; yet I still continue
to be silent; nay! if I had not still the hope for better things
to come, I should have retired from public life altogether.
Under such circumstances it is but natural, that even my
private correspondence must suffer; it so happens that you are
among the rest. I have yet a letter of Dr Holdheim, dated
March 1. 1858—to answer; I tried it often, but could not suc-
ceed. Dr Philippson has not had a line from me since last August,
and then I merely complained of the irregularity with which I
receive the publications of “the Institute”. Stein in Frankfort
has been expecting a letter from me, ever since last Juli. Coming

nearer home, Einhorn whom I must regard as one of my best friends
living, has to write two letters to my one, and others do not fare
better. I trust, as I do not wish to continue in this strain, that this
exposition will be accepted by you as a satisfactory apology for
my seeming neglect. In future, I shall endeavor to do better.

I have received the first number of the weekly “Occident.”
I must congratulate you upon its appearance; it is by far the
handsomest Jewish sheet of all I know; it really deserves to prosper.
I say this from the depth of my heart, altho' I cannot always
agree with the contents & tendency of your publications. Should
you wish my literary co-operation, I am ready to serve you; but,
as you must perceive from the above, I cannot promise any original
matter; and even translations of mine must not bear my name.

Here I am reminded to explain a fact which must seem to
you to be in contradiction with my exposition above: I allude
to the publication of “Hects Biblical History for Israelitish
Schools.” The work was ordered and undertaken by the School Com-
mittee of Dr Adler's Congregation, who appointed and requested me to make the translation. But I can show you from my cor-
respondence with Dr A. upon the subject, that I did not even respond
officially to that committee, but corresponded only privately with
the Doctor, and yielded only to his personal, earnest and re-
peated solicitations. All I received for my labor, are two copies
of the work, one from Dr A., and another from the publishers.

You undoubtedly have known that I suffered intensely last
summer, that I was confined to my bed,—with very short inter-
vals—for 15 weeks; 9 here and 6 in New York. But what
do you say to this: with the sole exceptoin of Dr Raphall (and
of course Dr Adler) not one of the Reverend (?) gentlemen ever

came to see me; Dr Fishel, Mr. Lyons & Isaacs would not even speak to me,
when we met. Indeed! I do not care about it; men who can thus
forget their position, thus violate the very first law of religion, and
manifest such a stupid fanaticism, are better “left severely alone”
in their glory and “?.”

I must let you also into the secret of an Mortara movement
here. Having been opposed by the Moise clique and others, the
meeting was a pitiful one; hardly 2 dozen Jews were present.
The Jews only, I am convinced, are united by their national
feeling only when there is something “to—'fress'”. A comparison
between the Swiss treaty affair and the Morara case, on one hand, and the
last Anniversary Dinner of our H. B. S. on the other, prove this fact beyond
all earthly doubt. I must confess, the more I see and hear of our
people in this country, the more I am convinced that Moses, were
he now to come amongst us, would again exclaim: !Hebrew
While they would allow no opportunity to pass, whenever it is in their
power, to oppress & persecute their own people and make them
feel their superiority—however questionable and counterfeited it
may be, they crouch and cringe before those of another creed, and
prove contemtible cowards whenever they are called upon to stand
up to their rights or defend their own Jewish-national affairs.
And in no city at is this more glaringly evident than in Charleston.
There they could exercise some influence, but they neglect it, to
please & flatter their Christian fellow-citizens; the defeat of Mr.
Mordecai, last fall, is exclusively attributable to the treachery of
his correligionists, especially, not exclusively, in the orthodox congregation.

But I must conclude; accept Mrs. M.'s & my own best regard
& wishes, and write soon to
By the bye,: How do you stand with
Dr Deutsch? Please send me the controversy
between the unknown Jew, yourself & Mr. Morais. I have heard of it, a few days
ago, but never seen it. You know what controversy I am alluding to.
